title: 115_hr1267
content: The Act may be cited as the "Personal Health Investment Today Act" or the "PHIT Act." Congress finds that almost 20 percent of American children aged 2 to 19 are overweight or obese, leading to increased healthcare costs. Research shows that investing in physical activity can reduce medical expenses, and offering financial incentives can encourage more Americans to be physically active. The purpose of this Act is to promote health and prevent disease, particularly related to obesity, by encouraging healthier lifestyles, providing financial incentives for healthy behavior, and increasing access to physical fitness activities. The United States ranks last in reducing preventable deaths from obesity-related chronic illnesses, and engaging in physical activities at a young age can significantly impact long-term health. Certain amounts paid for physical activity, fitness, and exercise are treated as amounts paid for medical care. Certain amounts paid for physical activity, fitness, and exercise are treated as amounts paid for medical care. Section 213(d)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include qualified sports and fitness expenses, such as membership at a fitness facility and participation in physical exercise programs. The amendment allows for qualified sports and fitness expenses, including membership at a fitness facility and equipment for physical exercise programs, with an overall limit of $1,000 per taxpayer ($2,000 for joint returns or heads of household). The amendment allows for qualified sports and fitness expenses at a fitness facility that meets specific criteria, including compliance with anti-discrimination laws. The amendment allows for qualified sports and fitness expenses, including exercise videos, books, and equipment used exclusively for physical activity programs. The amendment allows for qualified sports and fitness expenses, including exercise videos, books, equipment, and programs with components other than physical exercise. Effective for taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act.
